description: From Middle English cobill, kobill (used in various combinations with ston, stan (“stone”), note, nutt (“nut”), etc.), probably a diminutive of Middle English *cob, *cobb, ultimately from Proto-Germanic *kubb- (“lump; round object”). Equivalent to cob +‎ -le.

entries.meaning: (geology) A particle from 64 to 256 mm in diameter, following the Wentworth scale.
Alternative form of coble (a kind of fishing-boat).
(manufacturing) A piece of steel that becomes malformed during its manufacture or rolling.

verbs.description: cobble (third-person singular simple present cobbles, present participle cobbling, simple past and past participle cobbled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make shoes (what a cobbler does).
(transitive) To assemble in an improvised way.
examples: I cobbled something together to get us through till morning.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To use cobblestones to pave a road, walkway, etc.
